utterances: Salt-N-Pepa went on to sell over 10 million albums worldwide.
And they were the first female rap group to win a Grammy in 1995 for their song ""None of Your Business.
(Soundbite of song ""None of Your Business"")
(Singing) If I wanna take a guy home with me tonight, it's none of your business.
Today, Spin, as she likes to be called is still spinning records and hosting a national radio show.
She's here at our NPR West Studios.
Hey.
Hey
It's so great so see you.
I just have to describe you.
You look gorgeous.
Wow.
Thank you very much.
Very elegant.
I've been a big fan.
Do you how good that makes feel like?
I've been a big fan for a long time.
Thank you.
I appreciate it.
I really do.
So first, tell me about your DJ name.
How did you come with Spinderella?
I have the best name in the business.
I have to say - I don't know what God was doing.
He poured it out on me like blessings.
So, but the name came up from Hurby, our producer/manager at the time.
Actually, there was another Spinderella that started with the group when they originated it.
And I've been with the group since '87.
So, you know, that's many, many moons ago.
And Hurby, legendary producer in New York.
Yeah.
He was the creator of Salt-N-Pepa, the producer and everything else…
Yeah.
…in the beginning of our career.
Yup.
That's great.
So it sounds like a situation where you almost had to audition or something?
How did you go by this?
We'll just pass that over.
Very good.
(Soundbite of plopping)
I mean, that was the case because this was so different than what he's done all year.
He expressed that regret.
But then he talked a lot about that law-and-order message we've been hearing.
But he also talked broadly about the economy, about improving education, addressing poverty, talking about how education is key to providing opportunities.
At one point, he said, let our children be dreamers, too.
This was a pretty broad message, clearly aimed at moderates and Independents and even some of those year-to-year Republicans who are wondering what's going on with this campaign.
So did did a reporter's dream come true?
Were you able to find Amy after the speech and get her take?
I was frantically looking for her.
We did reconnect.
And, you know, she was really impressed, especially with that regret.
She said that showed some accountability.
That was the first thing that impressed me, yeah.
And I know he can't do everything he says.
But nobody can.
But the point is, he knows what needs to be done.
But she qualified that, like you said - Amy said there are 80 days left, and a lot can happen.
So she's going to keep listening closely.
And, you know, that's true.
Trump has shown many times one stray comment can undo a lot of this momentum.
And I think, just as important, he still said everything he said.
And a lot of people have been really offended by those comments.
And you can't just undo that with one speech.
Any reaction to the speech yet from Hillary Clinton?
It may be surprising.
They were not impressed with this speech.
The Clinton campaign sent out a statement.
They said that Donald Trump started this campaign by insulting people; he's continued to do so throughout the entire campaign - their quote was, ""without shame or regret."" So they're not buying it.
But that comes back to the ongoing question of this year; will the change last?
A lot of people who watched this speech said it had the fingerprints of one of Trump's new advisers, Kellyanne Conway.
She's someone who's going to be on the road with him, working with him day in, day out.
And she's someone who has a track record of reaching out to women voters, and that's particularly where Trump needs to make up this gap in the polls.
OK, talking to NPR's Scott Detrow, on the campaign trail in Charlotte, N.C.
Thanks, Scott.
Thanks, David.
The office of the US director of intelligence yesterday released a translated text of a letter written by al-Qaeda's second in command, Ayman al-Zawahiri.
The letter, dated July 9th, was intended for Iraqi insurgency leader Abu Musab al-Zarqawi.

US officials say they obtained it through counterterrorism operations in Iraq and it offers a surprisingly explicit look into al-Qaeda's short- and long-term goals, not just in Iraq but throughout the Middle East.
Joining us now to talk about it is Jessica Stern, the author of ""Terror in the Name of God,"" a lecturer at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government on terrorism.
She joins us by phone from her home in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
Nice of you to be with us today.
Hi.
You've read the letter.
Part of it seems to be a criticism of Zarqawi's tactics in Iraq.
Yes.
It is clearly criticizing his approach of attacking Shia and also slaughtering hostages, that he's sort of a little bit out of control, a little too rambunctious in his violence.
This idea, the letter says, of particularly the beheadings is counterproductive.
Yes.
He is obsessed with public relations.
He's obsessed with the image of the al-Qaeda movement.

And he feels that they're in a battle for the hearts and minds of ordinary Muslims, whom he considers to be ignorant in some cases or distracted or fearful and they have to be very careful about not allowing the enemy--that's us--to separate them from their strongest weapon, which is ordinary people.
And the letter is also critical, as you mentioned, of the killing of ordinary Shia.
At the same time, the letter describes Shiites as traitors.
Yes.
What's going on?
Isn't there a contradiction there?
Well, it's interesting, he very clearly distinguishes between leaders who presumably know what they're doing, the elite, and the masses whom he feels really don't know very much and are being used.
And he feels that really it isn't in their interest to kill ordinary Shia because no matter what they say to justify themselves, that it just--most Muslims see them as just murdering Muslims.
And that's counterproductive.
There is also--talking about the immediate and longer-term goals in Iraq and throughout the Middle East, Ayman al-Zawahiri seems to be looking toward an endgame in Iraq.
Yes.

He is predicting that US forces will leave relatively soon and will leave behind them a power vacuum and that there's an immediate competition about who will fill that power vacuum, either agents of the United States or the jihadis.
And he calls for the creation of as large of an emirate, as he calls it, as possible.
What does he mean by that?

Well, they see Iraq as just a kind of beachhead for the ultimate objective, which includes extending the jihad to neighboring secular countries--Egypt, Syria, Lebanon and Jordan--and beyond that in the future a clash ultimately with Israel.
They're trying to re-establish a caliphate...
Throughout...
...an Islamic regime, throughout the entire region.
